keywords: Caspian terns, double-crested cormorants, piscivorous colonial waterbirds, colony attendance, nesting chronology, avian management initiatives

abstract:
In order to monitor and manage populations of certain waterbirds, specifically Caspian terns, double-crested cormorants, and other piscivorous colonial birds like Brandts cormorants, researchers use a method that involves counting these species on East Sand Island in the Columbia River estuary.

To carry out this process, they set up observation blinds within designated plots or zones throughout the bird colony. By collecting data from these blinds, they are able to assess various aspects of these colonies, including attendance rates, nesting chronology (when birds begin building nests and laying eggs), and signs of disturbance that may impact the birds' behavior or survival.

This method is essential for understanding the dynamics of these bird populations and identifying factors that may limit their nesting or hinder the success of avian management initiatives aimed at reducing colony sizes. The collected data helps researchers make informed decisions to improve the overall health and wellbeing of these colonies, ultimately ensuring a thriving ecosystem within the Columbia River estuary.
